title: 110_hr638
content: The Act titled "Violent Crime Reduction Act of 2007" designates and provides assistance for high-intensity interstate gang activity areas under Title XV of the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994. The "Violent Crime Reduction Act of 2007" defines key terms and allows the Attorney General to designate high-intensity interstate gang activity areas based on specific criteria. Federal assistance is provided to these designated areas. The "Violent Crime Reduction Act of 2007" allows the Attorney General to designate high-intensity interstate gang activity areas and provide Federal assistance through the establishment of criminal street gang enforcement teams consisting of Federal, State, and local law enforcement authorities. Personnel can be reassigned or detailed from Federal departments or agencies to support these efforts. The "Violent Crime Reduction Act of 2007" authorizes the Attorney General to designate high-intensity interstate gang activity areas and establish criminal street gang enforcement teams. These teams consist of Federal, State, and local law enforcement authorities. Personnel can be reassigned or detailed from Federal departments or agencies to support these efforts. Funding is provided for the operation of these teams and for national and regional meetings to ensure effective operation through intelligence sharing and best practices. Each criminal street gang enforcement team established under the "Violent Crime Reduction Act of 2007" consists of agents and officers from various federal, state, and local law enforcement agencies. The teams are designated to address high-intensity interstate gang activity areas and operate through intelligence sharing and best practices. The Attorney General considers criteria for designating high-intensity interstate gang activity areas, including levels of gang crime, connection to violent crime, and resources committed by law enforcement agencies. The Attorney General may designate high-intensity interstate gang activity areas based on criteria such as levels of gang crime, connection to violent crime, resources committed by law enforcement agencies, and the potential allocation of additional federal resources. Additionally, the Attorney General is authorized to hire up to 94 Assistant U.S. Attorneys to address gang activities in these designated areas, with appropriations authorized as needed. SEC. 3. Grants to state and local prosecutors to combat violent crime and protect witnesses and victims of crimes. The Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 is amended to hire additional prosecutors, fund technology, equipment, and training for accurate identification of gang members and violent offenders, and increase successful prosecution of young violent offenders. Authorization of appropriations is also amended. The Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 is amended to authorize $20,000,000 for fiscal years 2008 through 2012. Grants are provided to establish state-wide crime prevention databases to track criminals, arrests, prosecutions, and convictions.
